title: How to Make Toum

steps.headline: Ensure all items are at room temperature, and that your tools are clean and dry.
steps.description: Water is your enemy here, and even very little of it can cause your emulsion to fail.

steps.headline: Put salt, pepper, and garlic into food processor bowl.
Pulse until garlic is finely chopped and well mixed with the salt, stopping occasionally to scrape the mixture to the center of the bowl.
steps.description: This is critical! Do not rush the processing of the garlic with the salt. Repeat the processing and scraping to center until the garlic is very fine - five to ten cycles.

steps.headline: Turn the food process on in constant mode.
steps.description: Take the lemon juice in one hand and the oil in the other, positioned to pour in to the the food processor bowl.

steps.headline: Slowly drizzle the oil into the food processor.
steps.description: The stream should resemble a thin thread - the key is to pour slowly. Initially, it will look like garlic and oil soup, but, when enough oil is added, the garlic, salt and oil will react and combine into a white emulsion. You'll hear a change in the food processor motor's pitch as well as see the change in the bowl.

steps.headline: At this point, continue to pour the oil as a thin stream, but also start pouring the lemon juice, also in a very fine stream.
steps.description: You should run out of juice before you've finished pouring the oil - that's OK!

steps.headline: The emulsion may build to the point that the additions of oil simply pool on top.
steps.description: If this happens, stop the processor and "cut" the emulsion with your scraper, ensuring you are creating a path for the oils to drain down toward the blade. Pulse the food processor to incorporate this oil into the toum.

steps.headline: Remove the top from the food processor, and cover the bowl with a towel (paper towel works fine), and refrigerate.
steps.description: This prevents any condensation from the sauce as it cools from falling back into it - added moisture can cause the emulsion to break, leaving you with a lemon-garlic oil (which is still usable for other purposes, I might add. Just a bit disappointing! ).

steps.headline: Once chilled, transfer to a suitable storage container, and keep refrigerated.
steps.description: Toum keeps a very long time - a month or more - before it begins to separate.

text: Ensure all items are at room temperature, and that your tools are clean and dry. Water is your enemy here, and even very little of it can cause your emulsion to fail. Put salt, pepper, and garlic into food processor bowl.  Pulse until garlic is finely chopped and well mixed with the salt, stopping occasionally to scrape the mixture to the center of the bowl. This is critical! Do not rush the processing of the garlic with the salt. Repeat the processing and scraping to center until the garlic is very fine - five to ten cycles. Turn the food process on in constant mode. Take the lemon juice in one hand and the oil in the other, positioned to pour in to the the food processor bowl. Slowly drizzle the oil into the food processor. The stream should resemble a thin thread - the key is to pour slowly. Initially, it will look like garlic and oil soup, but, when enough oil is added, the garlic, salt and oil will react and combine into a white emulsion. You'll hear a change in the food processor motor's pitch as well as see the change in the bowl. At this point, continue to pour the oil as a thin stream, but also start pouring the lemon juice, also in a very fine stream. You should run out of juice before you've finished pouring the oil - that's OK! The emulsion may build to the point that the additions of oil simply pool on top. If this happens, stop the processor and "cut" the emulsion with your scraper, ensuring you are creating a path for the oils to drain down toward the blade. Pulse the food processor to incorporate this oil into the toum. Remove the top from the food processor, and cover the bowl with a towel (paper towel works fine), and refrigerate. This prevents any condensation from the sauce as it cools from falling back into it - added moisture can cause the emulsion to break, leaving you with a lemon-garlic oil (which is still usable for other purposes, I might add. Just a bit disappointing! ). Once chilled, transfer to a suitable storage container, and keep refrigerated. Toum keeps a very long time - a month or more - before it begins to separate. Makes about 2-1/2 c.
